attachments.fallback:
[March 23rd, 2020 3:46 PM] sienna_leis: Good day! <@U0107A7161E> wanted me to share here a bit more about a solution that I've been working on with an MIT team, which is a citizen-centric open source ‘privacy-first’ digital solution for contact tracing for COVID-19 spread. It has three components: mobile app (<http://safepapths.mit.edu/|PrivateKit>), tools for health officials (SafePlaces) and plug-ins for partners. The digital *contact tracing using overlapped GPS trails* allows an individual to check if they have crossed paths with someone who was later diagnosed with the infection. Team is MIT, Harvard, Mayo and various startups. And the Mobile App (PrivateKit) is now available on playstore.

*Privacy*: We use either *on-device* calculation or use *encrypted trail match* with mathematical guarantees of privacy. Thus it avoids the ‘big brother’ surveillance state problem we see in China and South Korea where GPS matching solutions have been very effective but are <https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.08567|draconian>. The misinformation and distrust can cause civil unrest in a heterogeneous society.

*Why*: The approach will reduce panic that overwhelm healthcare systems and allow selective interventions rather than shutting down all socio-economic activity. So we expect this tool to empower not just an individual but also city officials and businesses that must keep continue the operations. Our research group has devised a series of solutions over the years for *civil resilience*. <https://splitlearning.github.io/> 

*Status*: We are finishing up contract negotiations with WHO and other key organizations. The solution is being built by a consortium of epidemiologists, engineers, data scientists, digital privacy evangelists, professors and researchers from reputable institutions. WHO, HHS and the Govt of India, Italy, Germany, Vietnam and many others are guiding the development. 

*Future plans*: In the early phases, emphasis is on rapid iteration and deployment for GPS-overlap solutions for contact tracing. In the later phases, the goal is *building encrypted computational methods that can be useful in any future societal disruptions.*
attachments.text:
Good day! <@U0107A7161E> wanted me to share here a bit more about a solution that I've been working on with an MIT team, which is a citizen-centric open source ‘privacy-first’ digital solution for contact tracing for COVID-19 spread. It has three components: mobile app (<http://safepapths.mit.edu/|PrivateKit>), tools for health officials (SafePlaces) and plug-ins for partners. The digital *contact tracing using overlapped GPS trails* allows an individual to check if they have crossed paths with someone who was later diagnosed with the infection. Team is MIT, Harvard, Mayo and various startups. And the Mobile App (PrivateKit) is now available on playstore.

*Privacy*: We use either *on-device* calculation or use *encrypted trail match* with mathematical guarantees of privacy. Thus it avoids the ‘big brother’ surveillance state problem we see in China and South Korea where GPS matching solutions have been very effective but are <https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.08567|draconian>. The misinformation and distrust can cause civil unrest in a heterogeneous society.

*Why*: The approach will reduce panic that overwhelm healthcare systems and allow selective interventions rather than shutting down all socio-economic activity. So we expect this tool to empower not just an individual but also city officials and businesses that must keep continue the operations. Our research group has devised a series of solutions over the years for *civil resilience*. <https://splitlearning.github.io/> 

*Status*: We are finishing up contract negotiations with WHO and other key organizations. The solution is being built by a consortium of epidemiologists, engineers, data scientists, digital privacy evangelists, professors and researchers from reputable institutions. WHO, HHS and the Govt of India, Italy, Germany, Vietnam and many others are guiding the development. 

*Future plans*: In the early phases, emphasis is on rapid iteration and deployment for GPS-overlap solutions for contact tracing. In the later phases, the goal is *building encrypted computational methods that can be useful in any future societal disruptions.*

text: <@U010KJBNGLX> has joined the channel

<@U010KJBNGLX> thank you for sharing your work! This team has two workstreams building out two contact tracing platforms (one redundancy)  with the MoH which are deployed in the next couple of days. We also have ongoing efforts connect contract tracing with data visualization and data analytics. I'm tagging some of our team members who may have questions about your process/decisions around your tool as they work through similar issues!

You can find the overview here: <https://docs.google.com/document/d/15RpO6YuoDdhcqN-4NagF0Q71ciPBBoL1g7jINNwF9gA/edit>
